ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lots of interesting things, geneva wheels, skotch-yokes, cams and all sorts of machine elements and designs. The final project at the end has a lot of potential moving forward.

This course reinforced my knowledge of manufacturing techniques while teaching me about both machine design and problem-solving strategies that would typically be seen in an industry setting. As someone who hopes go into product design, I hope that this course will be put to good use in the future.

This course teaches the basics of classic mechanical designs and design techniques. The are absolutely helpful skills to know as an engineer that are not taught in depth in any other course except a bit in MENG 325. Also covered in this class is a bit of dynamics that is much more palatable and intuitive than how dynamics was taught in MENG 383.
I learned about machine design and how to analyze machines with advanced mechanical engineering techniques.
a lot with mechanisms and how they work and the math behind them
Very helpful skills and tricks to aid in engineering work.
Design and analysis of four-bar mechanisms using Grashof criteria, CAD in Solidworks, kinematics and dynamics applied to mechanisms
I learned about different techniques for analysis of machines. This includes degrees of freedom calculation, various types of linkages, kinematics, and kinetics.
Very practical application of previously learned skills in ME 325 to machine design, analysis, and assembly.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: There are a lot of interesting things that the rest of the ME curriculum doesn't cover. Many kinds of mechanisms, nuts and bolts and tolerances and all manner of things like that. They're all interesting and have a lot of use for the mechanical engineer.

Weaknesses: Most of the weaknesses, I believe, are from it being in a virtual setting. I think more could be covered, or more completely, if the examples were relegated to the homeworks. Most of the class time was eaten up with example problems which are useful, but not necessarily anything new. Furthermore, the project could have been more well defined. For instance, having a set rubric for what's expected, a timeline and more checking in. Also, maybe having some example projects or things that could be done instead of leaving it totally open-ended. Perhaps also the project could be done in teams and have a wider scope, or be asked to take it more to completion (i.e. machining things, making a useful product) and more time could be devoted to this.

Overall, I thought the course was both engaging and informative. Also, it was one of the first examples of clearly seeing how information learned in class could be applied directly to the real world of the engineering industry. Also, Dr. Adrezin has a great understanding of students and was very accommodating, especially during a covid semester.

The biggest critique of the course was the handling of the final project. I felt like more guidance through the project would have been helpful, especially in the brainstorming period. Also, a small working budget for the course (and more accessibility to resources like laser cutters/a machine shop) would lead to better results. Nonetheless, I take that with a grain of salt since this was the first semester doing the course.

This course has a ton of potential. This being its first year being offered, it can definitely improve, but the type of content is exactly what I was hoping to move towards as I became an upperclassman in MechE. Firstly, I think the in-class solidworks tutorials should be more sparse. Considering MENG 325, which includes a design project that requires the use of CAD, is a prerequisite for the course, the tutorials that assumed we were clean slates seemed a bit unnecessary. With that extra time, either more mechanisms could be taught the same startegies could be taught more in-depth. The mastery-based learning is definitely a good way to go, but it might be better if advanced topics that were related were alluded to more often so that students knew where to start looking if they wanted to expand on what they learned/mastered. Lastly, the final build project should definitely stay, but I think there should be at least a bit more structure, maybe in the form of checkins and guidance. That way, students might be motivated to start earlier and be able to design products of the same caliber as in MENG 325.

Strengths - super interesting content. I really like the hands-on aspect of the class and feel like this is one of the few Yale MechE classes I have taken that I am genuinely interested in and can see applying to my later career. Also, the exams are super easy.

Weaknesses - Like any Doc A course, to an extent you get out of this class what you put into it. Assignments are maybe a little too open-ended. For example, you have to design a four-bar mechanism on Solidworks for one of the first assignments, and it can be as simple as four links or you can design an advanced machine with it. I feel like something between the two should be submitted, but there isn't much guidance on how to make the step between a simple thing you learn in class and more advanced/realistic applications. I think having some sort of guidance on what machines the mechanisms we learn about are used in could be helpful in taking that extra step to get more out of the class.
weakness: more information about the final project earlier and maybe have students start the project earlier
Strengths were very interesting work, amazing Professor.

Course had interesting applied aspects and felt like an opportunity to put together things we had learned in Machine Elements, Dynamics, etc. Some of the material felt a little abstract but Doc A reiterated the methods used in industry as well. The project was the most rewarding and engaging aspect of the course, and I think the class should be geared more toward it. Having some structure to guide students or timed deliverables could help because we all submitted a proposal and then kind of forgot about the project until reading week.

The primary strength of this course was the teaching by Doc A, who is an excellent professor. He makes all of the concepts easy to understand while giving us assignments that enforce the material. The course is excellent, and one way I can think of improving it is including more check-ins for the final project between the proposal and final product.

Weakness: I think there should be more hands-on, structured guidance for the final project (not as much as ME 325, though). Strength: it really felt like what I was learning mattered and would be useful in the future.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the kits were a good way to provide us with some of the tools necessary to do a project, especially since this was the first time we were tasked with interfacing machines learn in class with microcontroller components. Personally, I am very pessimistic about virtual learning, but I thought the class was still engaging, and Doc A did the best he could.
needs bit more materials for final project
Arduino kit and comprehensive lectures were strengths.

Recorded lectures are really helpful to look back on before exams and go over missed material. Would be really good to have in some form during regular semesters as well. Providing us electronics kits with a wide variety of sensors and components was very helpful and allowed us to experiment freely. Having a 3D printer from MENG 325 helped as well. Could be useful if we could request specific parts to be ordered if needed.
The arduino kits being sent to us helped enhance our final projects and made the virtual engineering experience great. The online lectures were also engaging through Doc A's lecturing style.
Lecture recordings are ever so useful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. You learn interesting things with a knowledgable professor, and hopefully it can be refined further in the future to be more streamlined so we know what is expected of us.

I would recommend this course to another student (given that they took a course like MENG 185 and/or MENG 325 that focused on design and implementation) since it's an engaging elective for junior/senior engineering students.

Assuming the class continues to be refined, I would definitely recommend the class to another student if they are interested in design, manufacturing, or the hands-on side of mehcanical engineering. For anyone who is more into the scientific theory side of mechanical engineering, it would definitely help them become a better engineer, but it might not be as useful for their career path.

I would definitely recommend this course. It was really interesting and not as high-level theoretical as a lot of other Yale classes. It is a hands-on, project-based course that lets us explore machine design and makes me feel like I am actually expanding my engineering ability.
yes! doc A is an incredible professor and this was a great class for juniors and seniors looking to further their machine knowledge
I definitely would recommend this course to an mechanical engineering student.

Yes, it's a great elective. Just make sure you put effort into the project, as that will be your main takeaway and experience from this class. Doc A loves to emphasize building a portfolio, so use this project to make something you can show off. It's also a good course for actually applying things you learned in MENG 325 and 383 especially, since those classes often feel a little too theory heavy.
I would HIGHLY recommend taking this course in order to learn very applicable engineering concepts through Doc A's teaching.
I would absolutely recommend this to another student who is interested in design engineering.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual Seminar / Lecture setting with assignments that involved coding, problem-solving, and building.
Virtual online lecture that was alsorecorded
Live virtual lectures that were recorded for later and a hands-on project for which materials were provided by Yale.
NA
Live virtual lecture and the recordings.
